newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: ASIAN EXOTICS - SING DOLLAR SLIDE SHAKES REGIONALS.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN EXOTICS - SING DOLLAR SLIDE SHAKES REGIONALS.

text.p: Southeast Asian currencies came under heavy pressure again on Tuesday as the Singapore dollar's sudden drop through a key support level triggered fresh buying of the U.S. dollar across the board, dealers said.
The Singapore dollar fell through the psychological 1.50 to the U.S. dollar level to hit a new three-year low of 1.5085 following comments by a Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) official.
The official of the de facto central bank told reporters at an economic briefing that the Singapore dollar's level was appropriate to what was happening in the market.
She said the U.S. dollar had been rising in currency markets and the Singapore dollar had depreciated by about five percent against the U.S. unit since the start of 1997.
The Singapore dollar was quoted at 1.5070/90 to the U.S. dollar at 0415 GMT against 1.4850/70 before the comments.
"Dollar/Sing is kind of stalling around 1.51 now. But if that goes, maybe we'll go to 1.53 eventually," a U.S. bank dealer said.
Dealers said the drop in the sturdy Singapore dollar had triggered selling of other Southeast Asian currencies as players increasingly grouped the region's economies together.
"Most of it was due to the Singapore dollar. It's now all a knee-jerk reaction. The four major regional currencies are all moving in the same direction," the U.S. bank dealer said.
He said the market was still short of U.S. dollars and a lot of long-term players, portfolio managers and corporations were looking to hedge their exposure.
The lack of aggressive intervention by Southeast Asian central banks was also playing a part in keeping regional currencies depressed, he said.
"The central banks realise that intervening aggressively just gives the speculators a chance to buy cheap dollars. So they're letting demand and supply determine the correct levels," he said.
Across the border, the Malaysian ringgit pulled back from an early 42-month low of 2.7930 to the dollar, but dealers said the currency remained vulnerable.
"All the indicators are showing an overbought situation, but nobody is looking at the indicators. Everybody out there seems to be buying dollars," a European bank dealer in Singapore said.
Dealers said the dollar would face some resistance around 2.7950 but they did not rule out a rise above 2.80 for the first time since dollar/ringgit was officially floated in 1973.
"We're staring at 2.80 now. And after that, I have no idea where it could go," the U.S. bank dealer said.
Spillover weakness from the ringgit and Singapore dollar pushed the Indonesian rupiah to an early low of 2,655, but it later recovered on dollar sales by Jakarta players.
"It's the contagion effect again. The market is a bit nervous, with spreads tending to widen again. But volume was moderate," a foreign bank dealer in Jakarta said.
He said stop-loss limits were triggered after the rupiah fell through the 2,620 level.
The rupiah was at 2,638/43 at 0415 GMT against an opening of 2,610/20.
The Thai baht was also weak but activity was relatively subdued with the onshore market closed for a Thai holiday.
Singapore dealers said the baht was likely to trade between 31.10 and 31.75 to the dollar in offshore markets, with further weakness expected once Thai financial markets reopened on Wednesday.

"It seems that after the IMF (International Monetary Fund) package, the market is expecting the baht to depreciate to 35 eventually, because a weak Thai baht would be good for economic recovery," a dealer said.
News that the IMF and other Asian donors had pledged to provide a $16 billion loan package to Thailand left the baht largely uninspired on Monday.
The Philippine peso weakened on heavy commercial demand for dollars, amid a shortage of the U.S. unit.
The peso was at 28.63/73 to the dollar at 0415 GMT against its previous close at 28.57. Manila traders said the central bank had offered to sell dollars at 28.65.
The Taiwan dollar recovered from its lows but remained weak at midday and dealers said it was soon likely to test the T$28.80 level, although the central bank was expected to moderate its decline.
They said the U.S. dollar's stronger stance against major currencies had triggered renewed buying of the U.S. unit from Taiwan importers.
